111111.content:
"Good work, everyone," Robin declared, projecting his voice outwards so that all the Shepherds could hear him from his point behind the battlefield. Though both Plegia and Valm were defeated, Risen still appeared from time to time, and it was up to them to protect the people of Ylisse from the undead warriors.

The particular battlefield they were on was different from the usual, mostly because the village had already been ruined before the Risen showed up, so there was nobody there anyway. Usually the Shepherds would proceed to go to each house and check to make sure nobody was harmed in the battle. This time, most of the Shepherds started to head straight back to the camp, except for the most meticulous Shepherds, like Miriel, Cordelia, and, of course, Robin.

As he expected, Robin found nothing in the dilapidated, sometimes crumbling houses he checked. When he came down to his last few houses, Cordelia and Miriel finished checking their sections of the village, so they left.

The last house he visited, despite being surrounded by the woods, was somehow the most intact compared to the rest of the village, and Robin theorized that perhaps a Mage of some sort lived there and put up enchantments to keep it standing. But whatever it was, it was gone now.

Robin opened the door to find the kind of furniture and decorations he'd expect from a Dark Mage, or perhaps one of those Shamans he'd read about in the Elibean histories. There was a cabinet full of strange, sometimes nasty-looking materials (he assumed they used to be used for ingredients), a cauldron, two large bookcases on the left wall of the room, and another cabinet on the right wall, this time with glass doors.

Curiosity reached his feet as they took him around the room, examining all the books and materials left in this mysterious person's house. He made his way over to the cabinet on the right, and found each and every shelf to be filled with different vials, beakers, and containers of varying shapes and sizes. But one in particular stood out to him: a simple vial of middling size compared to the rest, with a pyramidal bottom so that it could stand up without needing some sort of holder. This was also the only one with actual liquid inside, complete with a cork in the top to prevent any from spilling out.

Regardless, he decided to open the cabinet and take said potion, placing it in one of the incredibly secure pockets on his coat. Perhaps he could get Tharja or Miriel to look at it later and see if it did anything unique.
111111.title: A strange bottle found in an abandoned house

"R-Robin! I was sent back to the village to find you. What took you so long?" She said, clearly concerned about the length of time he'd taken.

1111111221121.content:
As Olivia grabbed his hand, Robin suddenly felt something rushing past his neck and shoulders, cascading down his back. He didn't have much time to think about what was happening to himself, however, as his attention was instead caught but what was happening to the woman dragging him along. Somehow, Olivia's hair seemed to be receding, vanishing into thin air, as colour drained from it. It didn't completely disappear, however, as it stopped receding after it reached a short, masculine-looking length, and had faded to be completely white. The hairties holding up her ponytail and holding together her braids simply fell out, falling to the ground. Her new hairstyle actually looked rather familiar, though Robin couldn't quite place where he'd seen it before.

"Olivia, you... your hair," Robin pointed out, trying to get her to stop dragging him so he could figure out what happened.

"Hm?" Olivia hummed as she turned around, only for her eyes to go wide. "R-Robin, y-your..." she mumbled, one hand covering her mouth while the other pointed towards Robin's head, finally letting go of his hand.

"Huh?" Robin mumbled as he turned his head, trying to see what Olivia was pointing at. That was when a long, pink lock of hair flapped into his line of sight. Alarmed, Robin quickly grabbed hold of it, only to find there was much more where that came from, and it was all firmly attached to his scalp. Long pink locks cascaded down from his head, reaching all the way to his rear. "This is..." he muttered, suddenly recognising the colour, and realising why Olivia's new hairstyle had looked so familiar.

"R-Robin, wh-what's going on?" Olivia asked. During Robin's examination of himself, she had discovered that she too had been changed, and was now clutching her rather short hair, her face a mixture of panic and embarrassment.

"I'm not sure," Robin answered, doing his best to keep calm. "But it seems like we've swapped hairstyles."

"I know, b-but how?"

Robin thought back, trying to figure out what might have caused the swap. As far as he could tell, nothing had been out of the ordinary about Olivia when she approached. It was possible someone had placed a hex on her, but there was no sign of anything of the sort. Was it him, then? Nothing like this had happened to him before, and nothing had happened to anyone else he touched today. And the only thing that had happened since his last contact with other people had been...

"The potion!" Robin suddenly exclaimed.

"What?"

"I found a potion in one of these houses, but I tripped and it got all over me. That must have caused this!"

"S-So, we just need to go back to the house and get another one?"

Robin shook his head. "No, it was the only one like it there, and all evidence of it disappeared after I broke it."

"Y-You mean... w-we're stuck like this?"

Robin racked his brain, doing his best to think of an alternative solution. Not only did he need to calm Olivia down, but he also wasn't fond of the idea of being stuck with Olivia's hair for the rest of his life. While it could easily be cut shorter, the colour wasn't as easily dealt with.

"Well, we do have multiple dark mages within the Shepherds, it's possible one of them knows something about this, and how to reverse it. Although, that'd mean heading back to camp looking like this." Judging by Olivia's reaction, she didn't seem particularly fond of that idea, and neither was Robin. He'd never live it down if someone saw him looking like this.

"Alternatively, the potion might still be on me. We swapped after we touched once I got covered with the potion, so maybe if we touch again, we'll swap back."

"But wh-what if it doesn't w-work? Or if it swaps s-something else?"

"Well... I suppose there's only one way to find out, isn't there?"

What did the pair decide on?

Ah, right. Talk with Cherche.' According to her, the wyvern and griffon stables had a few structural issues, so she wanted to talk with Robin about some improvements that Minerva and her had suggested while they worked on repairs.

He grabbed a quill (this one was enchanted to automatically draw ink from the inkwell, so he didn't need to keep dipping it) and some paper, and made his way down to the stables, where Cherche waved to him, smiling in her usual serene manner.

"Cherche. You and Minerva had some suggestions?"

"Why yes, we did. Firstly, Minerva expressed some concerns about the feeding troughs..."

This went on for about 30 minutes, where he shot down some of the more outlandish ideas ("How would we come up with a portable hot spring for wyverns?") and wrote down the more sensible ones, like making the feeding troughs a bit bigger for the wyverns with larger-than-average snouts and giving them a bit more space to roam around inside their stalls. When he was finished, he folded the paper in half and went to go bring the suggestions to the builders.

"Ah, why don't I handle that for you, and you go get some rest?" Cherche asked. Robin then turned around and thanked her, handing her the letter. She grabbed it, brushing her hand against his fingers, and went off to the builders to hand in their requests.

111112111.content:
He set down his manuscripts and walked over to his desk where the tome sat. Judging from the condition of the tome, it was clearly an incredibly ancient spell, and from the black colour it was likely some sort of dark magic spell. All Tomes they used contained an immense about of text which created the power with which they cast the spells, this is why despite only being able to cast a single spell they appear to be carrying around an entire book. The Tome itself is what gives the caster the ability to do this. He opened the book to find that, from the ruins transcribed it was unlikely this was like any spell he had ever seen. He decided the quickest way to work out what the spell was, was to cast. Even though he wasn't exactly adept at dark magic, what was the worse thing that could happen? Maybe he would blow up his room, or set it on fire but for some reason, he was feeling uncharacteristically impatient.

He opened the book to the page with it's incantation and began to speak the ancient words. As he began cast it, the book floated above the table, emitting a dark purple glow as a gust of wind began to swirl around him. Taken aback by the rather extreme reaction he stopped speaking the incantation but at this point it was too late as the spell was already in effect. A purple light shot from the book at him and made him keel over in pain, and after the pain nothing. It was as if he was loosing all sense of being. He could no longer feel any sensations coming from his limbs as he started to black out.

"Am... I dying...?" he thought as he lost consciousness. It's true, his life felt rather short. He didn't even remember anything of it prior to the shepherds finding him and taking him in. As his life flashed before his eyes he couldn't help but regret that...

1111121111.content:
If he had been more skilled with Dark Magic, maybe he could have been wise enough to not mess with the spell. Or at the very least he would have understood whether or not it was safe. Slowly he began to regain consciousness, and the feelings of his limbs returned to him. Blinking his eyes a little bit and looking around, he found that he was still in his tent. Well, at least at first this is what he thought as when he looked around the tent, he found that it certainly wasn't his. Rather than maps of the battlefield, books of strategy and the set of chess that was on his desk, he saw an alchemic work station on the desk to his left, and to his right what appeared to be an alter where some ritual would likely be held. On the shelves across the room from him, instead of book was bottles and jars filled with all sorts of strange herbs and off cuts of monsters and animals. Then he noticed it, the black hair that pervaded his peripheral vision. He turned to try and brush it away until he realised from the way it moved that it was his hair! But this was impossible, his hair was a white silver, not pitch black, unless that spell did something to him.

Pushing that issue to the side for now he looked down to quickly realised what happened to him. On his chest were two rather large breasts contained by a black material that provided just about as much coverage as a bra would, leaving a valley of cleavage visible. Additionally, a dark cloth draped over his shoulders almost like a cape, and a sheer, see-through material hugged his skin, the only real other clothing he seemed to be wearing. It didn't take a genius to figure out what had happened to him: He had somehow become Tharja. Or at the very least he now occupied her body he guessed thanks to the tome her had bought. Hesitantly patting his crotch a little bit it was clear that his manhood was no longer there, not that it would have fit given the tight fitting thong like garment he now donned. He was now a woman, from head to toe.

And not an ordinary one by any definition, but a very attractive one. The outfit Tharja often wore left very little to the imagination, however while she acknowledged how beautiful this body was, she didn't feel attracted to it in the way he normally would have. Rather it was almost a sense of pride of her own good looks. Sure she wasn't the most well endowed girl in camp but that wasn't something a couple hexes change. She stopped for a moment at that odd thought, 'cursing her friends'? That sounded downright horrible and yet, the very thought of doing this excited her. A smirk crawled over her face as she thought of all the fun she could have throwing a few curses around camp.

Once again Robin caught herself with these strange thoughts. Curses, Hexes, being the most beautiful? These weren't her own thoughts, it was almost as if Tharja's mind was starting to take her over. A feeling of anxiety began to settle as she realised what was happening. This spell from the black tome didn't just make her look like Tharja, it was starting to make her Tharja in ever way possible. She figured the best way to sort this issue was to get a hold on the tome that caused this once again. That combined with her new knowledge of dark magic would be more than enough to reverse this nightmare.

Her legs quivered a little, her inner thighs brushing against each other as she tentatively took her first steps as Tharja. Her long pitch black hair grazed her back and neck is a subtle yet utterly foreign way as she moved. With her new assets and wider hips his sense of balance was out of whack, the gold heels on her feet not really helping with this. Each step felt unlike anything she'd experience, her hips swinging voluptuously each time she minced forward. After what felt like a rather long walk, a fact that now highlight how less physically able his current form was, he reached his tent.

As she carefully peaked through the entryway of her old tent saw her old body standing in the room looking at something on the desk in the corner. As she stood there peaking around the corner she was overcome with an odd feeling, the acute awareness that the man standing just a few meters away from her was incredibly handsome. The very sight of him made her blush a little bit, it was a feeling of affection, the feeling that this man was special. He's the one that she was destined for... Robin quickly snapped himself out of his thoughts, realising that Tharja's personality was once again taking control of him. As he walked into the doorway properly this time, the man in the tent turned to face her. "You're... well, suppose to be me right now... or something..." he said, an uncharacteristically puzzled look on his face.

"Yes, I'm Robin Tharja... I think the spell swapped us around..." she said in her now womanly voice. While it was clear the spell was now extending to affect his speech, it appeared the real Tharja had understood what was going one.

"It'd odd... I really don't feel like myself... curses, hexes, all the things I've spent my life doing feel so... foreign to me now." he muttered, "So... how did this happen?" he asked. Robin took time to explain the book and how the spell had happened, though as he explained he realised he didn't know exactly why the spell had swapped him and Tharja around.

"Well... between the two of us I think we should be able to figure this tome out!" Robin said. Opening up the book, the ancient text that was written in it still didn't appear any more coherent, even with Tharja's knowledge of dark magic rattling around in his brain. After what felt like hours the two of them had finally decided to give up deciphering this book, "It's too hard!" the tacticians body spoke out, "I figure the best way around this is to just try it out again!" he said, clearly a little bit frustrated.

"I guess so... or we could stay like this..." Robin offered. "I won't lie, but I've started to question who it is I am. I don't feel like 'Robin' anymore... all these things... swordplay, strategems... it all seems rather foolish to me." the newly minted woman approached her old body, "I've even fallen head over heels for my old body... nothing about me feels like this tactician. To me, I am Tharja. Nothing else seems right."

After much discussion, they finally came to a decision.

Robin was about to make his decision and announce it for all to hear, when suddenly all faded into a dark, fogged mist.

The still spell-swapped Robin was taken back by the newfound scenario, with utter concern and shock expressed within his face. Yet, no matter where he looked, he only saw swiveling darkness...

To his right, he heard a sinister laugh echo throughout the mist. "Show yourself!" Robin commanded.

Elapsing from within the darkness, a figure emerged. It was a brigand of immense size, with a shimmering bandana wrapped across his forehead!

"You think you can stand up to Batta the Beast!?" the figure announced. Robin drew his sword and the battle commenced.

After a flash of steel, the brigand was still standing, unscathed, while Robin was heaving with a near-fatal wound.

"But... but how!? My sword should have countered your axe!" Robin yelled at his opponent.

Batta chuckled, "Ha! I thought you were a strategist!" He raised his axe towards Robin and stated, "This, is a Swordreaver! Isn't it beautiful? I crafted it out of my pure malice for protagonists like you! It counters swords, no matter what your silly textbooks tell you!"

Robin raggedly drew in his breath. He had never seen a weapon of that caliber before... It must have come from a time when adventures were less about marriage and redundant character shipping and more about actual strategy and story narrative!

Robin exclaimed in response, "Even so, how did you hit me with only 1 point in skill? The odds are against your hitrate!"

The marauding brigand laughed once more and simply stated, "The numbers fool you, my dear boy! Even with a 60 hitrate, the odds are in my favor due to my weapon advantage." He wiped the slick edge of his axe with the tips of his fingers. "Now... It is my turn." Batta concluded.

No! Robin made the simplest mistake in the book! You never can make the first attack if you don't check the odds clearly...

It was at this moment, with a clean slash of his Swordreaver, that Batta extinguished the last of Robin's life points. The poor protagonist fell to the ground with a thud as the dark mist covered over him.

With a flash of his smile while turning his back, the brigand disappeared into the fog and the resonating sounds of his footsteps slowly faded away.

Looks like you had... a ghost of a chance!

Apparently his wish made in panic was granted in the most twisted way possible so no one else would be by Chrom's side for longer than who he now was. He had her narrow waist, wide hips, full butt and, probably everything else as well. Robin put his hand to his crotch and confirmed that he was use to having down there was gone. This had the effect though of giving his walk a feminine sway.

"Wonderful, Robin, but now we will try it in a more restricting outfit." Maribelle lead Robin to her closet as she got in dressed in a fancy ballgown and some more fancy and higher heels. Robin was made to go through the whole process again in his new outfit. Lots of it was easy due to how ingrained his new posture was, but he underestimated how much harder it was with this wide dress and taller heels. Robin had to gently lift up his skirt when he walked and it was difficult walking and standing straight in these new heels. After a while, Maribelle said that he was done with the first lesson.

Robin breathed a sigh of relief, but he had to admit he was a bit nervous. Robin noticed that he now walked, stood, and sat just like a high class lady would. He didn't even have to try, it was all natural to him now. Robin couldn't even force himself to change his posture, it just went back to how it was supposed to be. Robin was scared, he didn't expect Maribelle's lessons to be so effective, at this rate if this continued, he would probably be unable to act in any way except like a lady. Maribelle smiled as she looked over Robin. He was dressed so femininely with his posture prim and proper. "Perfect, you look exactly how a lady should. Next we shall move on to lesson 2..."

111113221222122222111112111211222211221.content:
"A lady must always look her best. Blemishes, rough skin, and imperfections are simply not allowed." Maribelle lead Robin over to the vanity who instinctively smoothed his skirt before sitting down. Maribelle showed him each type of cosmetic he could possibly use before lecturing him on when to use it and how to apply it. Robin had to go through an intensive quiz by Maribelle making sure that he memorized it all. Next they moved on to actually applying the makeup. Maribelle watched over Robin like a hawk to make sure there wasn't even the smallest mistake. It took quite a lot of tries before Robin was able to get it completely right. Robin blushed as he looked at his reflection. Thanks to the makeup, he looked even more beautiful than ever before.

Maribelle complimented Robin on how he looked and then moved on to hair care. Like with the cosmetics, she taught and quizzed him on every hair product that she knew of. Maribelle undid Robin's hairstyle and she forced him to restyle it himself. It was a laborious process as Robin struggled immensely with the complicated hairstyle that Maribelle had. With Maribelle's tips and guidance, Robin eventually managed to style his hair like Maribelle's. When that was finished Maribelle spoke up again. "A lady follows a strict schedule. Doing your hair and makeup and touching it up throughout the day must be an instinctual routine. Thus, it is required that you can perfectly yet swiftly go through the routine."

Maribelle removed Robin's makeup and undid his hair, making him do it all over but with a strict time limit. Robin thought the task to be impossible as he went through it over a dozen tries. It was either that he took too long or that he made a mistake in his haste. All the while, Maribelle talked with Robin as she worked out a schedule for him on when he would work on his hair and makeup. Through constant attempts, Robin eventually succeeded in doing it, even doing it again a second time. At this point, Robin didn't even need to think about it. His hands naturally moved from memory to do what he needed, flawlessly and with incredible efficiency. The ease that he now did it, was what scared Robin the most. He could tell that he was slowly but surely becoming a lady.

To finish up the lesson, Maribelle removed the gloves that Robin was wearing. She taught him how to file his nails, clean them properly, and push back the cuticles. Robin was reminded that a lady did not do manual labor and that his hands and skin could clearly represent that. Similarly he was told that he always needed to wear a pair of gloves to keep his hands clean, and keep a parasol with him at all times to protect his increasingly delicate skin from the sun. Now that Maribelle was satisfied with how he did with lesson 2, she moved onto to lesson 3.
111113221222122222111112111211222211221.title: Keeping up appearances

1111132212221222221111121112112222112211.content:
"Robin, you may look like a lady but you do not yet sound like a lady." Maribelle decided that the first step was to get Robin to sound like a woman. Robin was instructed on how to raise and inflect his voice. Robin found it to be the hardest lesson so far. Every time he talked he was either met with criticisms of his voice being too low pitched or too high pitched. Robin also had to make sure that his voice was soft, but not too quiet. It was a grueling task with Robin having to try every way he could until he found the right voice.

Now that Robin had gotten his voice to sound convincingly feminine, Maribelle moved to training Robin to speak like a lady. Robin had to start with tongue twisters and other exercises to make sure that his enunciation was perfect. As usual he was strictly reprimanded if he misspoke at all. Robin was shocked by how difficult they could be. Getting his voice to sound elegant and high class was its own struggle. Robin had to pay close attention to how Maribelle spoke so that he could finally get it down/

The next part was the one that Robin dreaded the most, he had to practice speaking with Maribelle. Every sentence he spoke was criticized in every way imaginable. Maribelle would find some grammar flaw and then Robin had to go through a detailed grammar lesson until he got it right. When it wasn't grammar, Maribelle would pick out the words he used. She made sure there was absolutely no slang or other incorrect words to be found in his speech. Robin also was given many synonyms for his words that Maribelle said were better suited for a lady like him.

Robin went on to the next exercise that was Maribelle and Lissa giving him a prompt for him to speak about. He blushed when he heard what the first one was and prepared himself. "Thank you Maribelle for your gracious aid and your impeccable lessons. Before I was a ruffian devoid of grace or class, but now I have improved immensely as I became a lady. I vastly prefer the elaborate and exquisite dresses I wear now as opposed to my old ratty, drab robes." Robin said while Maribelle and Lissa giggled, with Robin embarrassed at what he had to say. Lissa was glad to see how things were progressing, the feminine and refined voice that came out of Robin's mouth now perfectly matched his new appearance. Robin had to go through more prompts that were all about reaffirming himself as a feminine lady and a high class noble. Robin was horrified that he even thought now in a proper and refined speech and had to try hard to remember that he wasn't a lady or a noble. Maribelle gave another smile as she complimented him once more before going on to the next lesson.

1111132212221222221111121112112222112211.content:
"Robin now that you are a lady, you are also now a noble. For this reason, your next lesson will be on how to properly conserve with your fellow nobles." Robin wasn't looking forward to the lesson, he never cared about all that formal talk with nobles. Maribelle grabbed his attention before speaking up once more. "A true noble is always proud and confident. So first, you must acknowledge and accept you are a noble and then be proud of it." Robin gulped as he saw the large stack of books that Maribelle brought out for him.

Robin had to sit and listen while Maribelle read from the books to him. They were all about what it meant to be a noble, their responsibilities and what was expected of them, and their importance. Maribelle would chime in from time to time with her own opinions. When she was done, Robin had to give his own thoughts on the subject. He did what she said, but Maribelle told him to be more detailed and complex while also talking about how it related to him personally and why he was proud to be a noble. Robin had to think long and hard about it for a good while. He had to give a very long and thoughtful response but eventually he came up with a satisfying answer to her. After all of that, it was incredibly difficult for Robin to not think of himself as a noble. In fact as much as he hated to admit it, a part of him was proud of it too.

"Robin an important part of interacting with other nobles is to know their social standing. Even among nobles there is people of high and low standing and you must take that into account when conversing with them. However never forget that a noble of any standing is still a noble, so you must treat them with that due respect." Robin first had to learn how to quickly distinguish the social class of anyone he met so he would be able to tell even when dealing with foreigners. He was confused at first by all the subtle details that he had to look for so that he could figure it out, but he was slowly learning it. Robin learned and had to recite every noble family in Ylisse, their history, and all of their members.

Now that everything was prepared, they moved onto to the details of conversation. Maribelle told Robin every little detail on what was appropriate to talk about with other nobles. She discussed in great detail what high class ladies spoke about and their interests. Maribelle repeatedly stressed the importance of not offending another noble whether by accident or on purpose. Robin found it a prickly subject but Maribelle helped him get it. Robin also practiced addressing nobles of higher standing by using Chrom as an example. Maribelle worked hard to stress that he needed to address Chrom as Lord Chrom and to see him as such. It was very difficult for Robin since Chrom was his best friend but Maribelle was very persistent. Eventually Robin caved in and accepted the idea and saw Chrom in a new light. After that, Robin practiced with Maribelle and Lissa on how to speak with fellow ladies. Maribelle sighed as she felt that she ended up having to teach Lissa about it as well.

Robin thought they were done with the topic until Maribelle said they was one thing left about it. "One of the most important parts for a lady when conversing with other nobles is how to converse with potential husbands." Robin blushed with embarrassment as he heard that she would teach him about getting a husband. Maribelle bombarded him with all sorts of tips and tricks on how to attract a man. Robin had to listen as Maribelle went on at length about what a lady looks for in a man. Likewise Robin had to learn what a noble gentleman looked for in a wife. It was all so embarrassing to him but nonetheless he had to know what to do on dates or how to talk with a boyfriend, and even how to kiss them. When it was over, Robin was blushing furiously having realized that if this continued then there was a real chance he would have to get a boyfriend. Robin knew if that happened then his fate as a lady for life was sealed. Maribelle and Lissa smiled and giggled at each other before they moved on to Robin's fifth lesson
1111132212221222221111121112112222112211.title: Interacting with other nobles

1111132212221222221111121112112222112211.content:
Maribelle explained the Robin's fifth lesson was on high-class fashion as she began getting everything ready. She brought tons of dresses and other clothes before shoving a stack of books into Robin's hands. He looked on with horror at the mountain of fashion tomes that he was holding right now. Maribelle started off with the basics as she told Robin about fabrics and which ones were best. Next she talked about the types of clothes that ladies wore and began breaking down their component. Robin had to learn about and be able to identify all the different types and variants of dresses, heels, skirts and so on. Maribelle then brought up how he needed to change what he wore depending on the season and informed him on what clothes were appropriate for each season.

Now that he knew about clothing, Robin moved on to the next step. Maribelle got excited as she started shoving dress after dress into Robin's hands. Robin had to try on each of the dresses. While he did that, she lectured him on how to identify a great outfit by how it felt and fit. Maribelle was training him to be able to tell everything about an outfit just by wearing it. Robin was told repeatedly that a lady needed to have the ability to identify quality at first sight. Maribelle said it was important to know if an outfit was worth trying on. She brought out more clothes and put Robin to the test of seeing which ones were low quality. When he was done with that part, he then had to identify fakes. Maribelle informed him that a lady only wears authentic clothing. It was a very hard task as Robin had to pay attention to every little detail. If there was even the smallest thing he didn't know about the dress then he wasn't able to do it. Robin was relieved when he had finally made it.

Maribelle then began to discuss the qualities that made up a great outfit. She went at length especially on how a lady should judge their clothing. She wanted to make sure that Robin understood his new feminine clothes were lovely and wonderful while his old robes were ugly. Robin had to sit through a very long lecture until he had grasped it well enough. Then came the incredibly difficult exercise. Robin had to give 50 reasons why his old clothes were hideous and ill-suited to him now and then give 50 reasons why the dress he was wearing was so wonderful. He couldn't believe that it was even possible for him to do it. Robin gave it a couple of tries to little success. He decided that the only way to do it was too place himself in the mindset of a high class fashionista. When he did that, Robing was finally able to do it and with ease even. It came at the price of leaving Robin a bit stuck in the mindset though. Now whenever he thought about his old clothes he couldn't help but feel some disgust while likewise feeling some joy at the feminine attire in the room.

The last part of the lesson was Maribelle teaching Robin how hair and makeup fit into fashion. He learned how to style his hair and do his makeup to best fit with what he was wearing. Maribelle also discussed current fashion trends and ways to predict and keep up with the latest trends. Maribelle smile as she looked over Robin. "Robin you are doing absolutely wonderful. I can tell that you were just meant to be a lady. You have just one lesson left for me to teach you."
1111132212221222221111121112112222112211.title: High-class fashion

1111132212221222221111121112112222112211.content:
Maribelle told Robin that his final lesson was on proper behavior. He wondered what exactly she meant by that while she was getting everything ready. Maribelle started off with greetings and how to properly curtsy. Robin learned very quickly that she was incredibly strict about getting his curtsy to be absolutely perfect. He had to do it about 200 times before she finally accepted it. She lectured him about how to politely end a conversation before moving on to manners. Robin was first taught how to gently stifle a giggle with his hand, and to always wipe his mouth when he ate. Maribelle stressed the importance of always being courteous and respectful especially to other nobles. Robin was trained to always be calm, composed, and graceful. Maribelle said that most of all as a noble he was expected to be a pillar of virtue.

The final step was on proper interests for a lady. Robin was first greeted with a long lecture on everything a lady should not do or be associated with. Some of the interests he was expected to have were shopping, trying on dresses, and teatime. Maribelle went on a lot how important it was for a lady to drink tea. Robin was told that it was more than just drinking something but also a social event and the chance to speak with others. She was very intent on making sure that Robin knew everything there was about tea. Robin had to hold and drink his tea in a certain way. He also was expected to be very particular about his tea and only drink the finest tea that there was,

Maribelle decided the that lessons were finished and went about testing Robin. She checked his mannerisms, posture, speech, and knowledge. Robin answered every question with ease showing off his new vast knowledge. He was shocked at how much information he was able to cram in but he felt that he forgot about a lot of other stuff in the process. Maribelle was very impressed with his posture and mannerisms as well. Every movement and way he held himself exuded pure femininity and grace. Between his elegance, sweet smile, beautiful dress, perfectly done hair and makeup, almost anyone besides Robin himself would just see a lovely lady. Maribelle told Robin how proud she was of how he did with Lissa agreeing. Robin responded by giving them a curtsy and thanking them for everything they did.

Robin realized a bit too late that he had made a grave mistake. With Lissa guarding the door, he decided to wait it out until the lessons were over before figuring out what to do. He now knew that he greatly underestimated how powerful Maribelle's lessons were and how dedicated she was into making sure he learned them by heart. He had to admit though that Maribelle was very skillful at molding someone into a proper lady. Robin had so many new ladylike habits that were so deeply ingrained that his body just followed them by instinct. Even his mind was flooded with all sorts of new beliefs, knowledge and interest. Large parts of his mind were trying to push him to fully accept being a lady. Robin wondered if it was even possible to fully go back to how he was before. Even most of the parts of his mind that resisted were affected heavily by Maribelle's lessons. They were much more noble minded and quite proud of the fact as well.

Maribelle pondered what she should do next alongside Lissa. Robin was close but they wanted Robin to not just fully accept being a lady but also to embrace it. They figured that they should do something big to test his newfound skills in a real life setting. They were sure that it would also give him the final push that he needed.

"Hello Robin," Chrom said. He turned to Lissa and Maribelle. "Lissa, Maribelle, may I ask the two of you to leave? I need to talk with Robin in private."

Chrom sighed as he patrolled the shepherds campgrounds. Robin and the majority of the army had left for a supposed Brigand invasion at the border. "Nothing serious." He had said. "So I'll need you to stay here, keep watch of thie border. We wouldn't want it spilling into Ylisstol."

"It'll only be a few days." Chrom ruminated over his words. Robin, while a brilliant tactician, certainly wasn't the best at assigning him with any interesting tasks. The camp was practically empty. Vaike, Lissa, Tiki; all gone. He had even taken Lucina. Aimlessly marching through the camp, Chrom was stuck for things to do. He could go see Marribelle, though he wasn't sure he wanted to put up with her ceaseless complaints. He could check in Thatja, but... Actually maybe he shouldn't. As he almost reached the edge of the site, he was hocked by the sudden loud *crash* from behind him.

He rushed to the origin of the sound, Nowi's tent, only to see the manakete wrapped tightly in blankets and rope, struggling against her bonds. "Nowi? Who did this to you?" Chrom asked, quickly scanning the rest of the tent. He drew his sword, carefully cutting the rope restricting the girl's movements. She still struggled frantically, even after the bonds had been broken. "It's okay now, Nowi. Whoever did this to you doesn't seem to be around any-" A sharp pain ran through his hand, causing him to grunt in pain. He looked down, only to see the green-haired girl biting onto him. "N-Nowi! What are you doing?" He shouted, as the girls eyes slowly went from glazed to focused.

"Phew, I feel so much better now." She smiled, having changed back to her normal cherry demeanour. Before he could so much as respond to the girl, her daughter barges inside, carrying an apothecary's worth of potions and herbs.

"Mom-Chrom!?" Nah was just as stunned as he was, almost dropping everything. "Did you untie her?" She spoke with urgency, the girl quickly placing her potions on a nearby desk, clutching her dragon stone tightly.

"Don't worry Nah, I'm fine." Nowi answered. Nah merely glared at her, a cheeky smile forming on her mother's face. Nah sighed. "... She was tied up for a reason, you know. Mom was sick... I didn't want her hurting anybody." Nah placed the stone back in her pocket.

"So you tied her up? Without telling anyone?" Chrom responded, a little annoyed that a member of the shepherds would be so secretive. "I didn't want to worry you all." She said, running her eyes up and down Chrom's body.

"Seriously honey, I'm feeling so much better now."

"It's not you I'm worried about. Chrom, did she bite you?" Nah asked, concerned.

"It's fine, she barely even broke skin." Chrom extended an arm, showing off the small , barely bleeding bite mark. Nah sighed, glancing away. "No... It's not fine... You've been infected by her." Chrom' suddenly felt a slightly dizzying sensation, unsure if it was solely because of the news, or whatever disease he had contracted. "So? Is it bad?"

"You can't die from it, but..."

"But?"

"But I don't know what it'll do to a human let alone a man." The dizzying sensation started to quicken, as Chrom found it harder and harder to stand or stay focused.

"Oh, I know!" Nowi smiled, albeit guiltily. "You told me you didn't." Nah growed, before turning back to the unsteady prince. "It'll..."

His clothes were much more loose, threatening to fall off if he moved the wrong way.

Eventually, the pain seemed to ease off. The dizziness and nausea remained, alerting him that this was not over yet, but it seemed the first phase had completed.

"Hehe, you look so small," Nowi said with a giggle.

"Mom! Please!" Nah scolded, clearly not pleased with how casually Nowi was treating this.

Nowi was right though. As Chrom slowly pushed himself up into a kneeling position, he found that, were he standing, he'd probably only be able as tall as Nowi and Nah were. He didn't have a mirror to observe himself in, but he guessed he'd look just as young as well. Some of his garments had fallen off, but he still had enough on to be decent.

"Oh Gods. I am so sorry, Chrom," Nah apologised, as she saw what Chrom had become.

"It's not your fault," Chrom managed to get out as he battled the nausea. Just as he would have guessed from his appearance, Chrom's voice sounded younger and higher pitched, but for the time being as still male, a fact he could confirm by the feeling in his pants.He reached a hand up to his ears, finding them to still be rounded, rather than the pointed tips Manaketes had. Chrom entered his tent, maps strewn across the table he'd set up inside. A large group of Risen had been spotted nearby, and he saw it as his duty to take them out, to keep his people safe. Of course, raw strength alone would no win the day, which is why he'd called his tactician, Robin, over to to try and come up with a plan of attack. Robin had been in the middle of something when he'd asked her for help, but she said she would come momentarily. Chrom moved towards to table, intending to tidy up the maps and put away any irrelevant to the discussion, when suddenly he was overcome with a wave of dizziness. Struggling to hold it together, Chrom drew his sword, his other hand clasped to his head, as he looked around for a potential attacker that could be causing this, but saw none. And then all of a sudden, all sensation disappeared, as if he'd passed out, and yet, he was still conscious.

But a few moments in the black void he'd found himself in felt like hours to Chrom, but before long, sensation returned, although something didn't seem quite right. He had assumed he'd wake up to find himself lying on the ground after passing out, or at least be left in the same standing position he'd been in before the void had engulfed him. However, he now found himself in a crouching position, surrounded by bushes, and he was now outside instead of his tent. His sword has also vanished from his hand. He was definitely still at the Shepherds' camp, as he could see his tent not too far away, but he'd been moved outside of it. Why?

Chrom looked around for anyone that might have moved him out here after he passed out for some reason, when suddenly, he noticed some long, dark hair, flowing into the edge of his vision. His hair was nowhere near that long, nor was it black. He reached up to grab it, and see if it was truly attached to his head, but instead his attention now moved to the hand that had risen up into his line of sight. He was certainly controlling it, but it was not his hand. It was slim and feminine, with long, purple nails. The black hair he'd seen was now the least of his worries. Chrom looked down at himself, only to discover a mountain of cleavage hanging from his chest, held in a tight, black top. Below it, a dark brown body stocking covered up the rest of the clearly feminine curves that sat beneath the breasts. He had seen this body and outfit before; it belonged to Tharja, a Plegian dark mage he'd managed to recruit during the war against Plegia. But if he was viewing her body from this angle, then...

"What's go-" Chrom cut himself off as he reached his hand up to his throat. That was almost certainly Tharja's voice that had escaped his mouth. That the view of his body didn't convince him, then that certainly did; he had somehow found himself in Tharja's body. He wasn't entirely sure how it happened, but he had no doubt one of Tharja's hexes was involved. He'd heard tell of Tharja's hexing around the camp, but he'd yet to become the victim of one himself, until now. Regardless, Robin would be over any moment now for their strategy meeting, so he needed to get this sorted out now.

He quickly stood up, wobbling a bit due to his new center of gravity and the heels Tharja wore, and walked over to his tent. Now that he was walking, he couldn't understand why it had taken him as long as it did to notice that he wasn't in his own body. Everything felt vastly different, from the slight bounce of his chest, to the void between his legs as his thighs rubbed together. It was an altogether odd experience, one Chrom had no intention of experiencing for any extended period of time.

Thankfully for Chrom, inside his tent, he saw his own body, seemingly examining itself. "Tharja," Chrom called out, trying to sound commanding, although to tone didn't quite come across right with Tharja's voice.

His body turned around, looking at him with a dark glare. "Hm, so you are in my body after all, then," his body stated with a rather brooding tone, confirming that Tharja was in fact the one in his body.

"What's going on here? Why have we switched bodies?" Chrom asked, attempting to keep his cool, despite the situation.

"I had intended to cast a hex on your to make you lose interest in Robin so I could have her all to myself. Clearly I made a mistake somewhere along the line, and it did this instead."

"Well, switch us back, then. I need to meet with Robin about our strategy for the upcoming battle, and I can't very well do that while I'm in your body." Chrom crossed his arms, before immediately uncrossing as he realised that made them push against his breasts.

That seemed to catch Tharja off guard. "I... uh..."

"That's what I thought." Robin crossed her arms across her chest. "Tharja, I know where the real Chrom is now, so you can't just pretend to be him to get me to like you. Now give Chrom his body back, this isn't going to get you what you want."

Tharja looked down in silence, realising that she'd been caught. The one person she needed to not know about the swap now knew. Chrom shuffled around awkwardly while Tharja thought about her next move. He hoped this would be over soon and he'd get his own body back, but he worried that Tharja might have another trick up her sleeve.
11123222221122122211.title: Chrom and Robin confront Tharja

111232222211221222111.content:
Tharja let out a frustrated sigh. "Well, I suppose there's no reason for me to keep this body anymore then," she said. Chrom could feel his heart racing. It had worked! Their plan had worked! He was going to get his body back!

Tharja closed her eyes, and began to utter words that Chrom didn't understand. He assumed she was casting the spell that had swapped them in the first place. Robin remained wary, however. She knew Tharja better than Chrom did, thanks to their frequent encounters. It didn't seem like Tharja to give up so easily when she was involved, so either she was planning something, or she was enjoying Chrom's body as much as he was her's, which was to say, she wasn't.
111232222211221222111.title: Tharja casts the body-swap hex again

1112322222112212221112.content:
As she finished her incantation, Chrom noticed Tharja stumble a bit, as the dizziness that had accompanied the first swap began to wash over her. However, strangely enough, he felt completely fine, save for the fact that he wasn't in his own body. Was it simply affecting her faster than it was him?

His hopes were dashed as he heard Robin next to him. "Urgh, what's... what's going on?" She was holding a hand to her head as she struggled to stay standing, the world spinning in front of her.

"Robin?" Chrom asked, concerned. He did his best to hold Robin up as the pieces began to fall into place in his mind. He wasn't experiencing the dizziness, but Robin was. There could only be one explanation. "Tharja!" he shouted at the culprit behind this. He caught a smirk on what was formerly his face right before Tharja passed out, flopping onto the ground. At about the same time, Robin collapsed in his arms, and he slowly laid her down on the ground.

Chrom's heart was racing, but for an entirely different reason this time. Tharja had cast her hex, but he was still stuck in her body, and Tharja had swapped herself with Robin instead. Instead of sorting this out before it became too big of a problem, it had simply turned into an even bigger mess. Would he ever get his body back? He was beginning to think that may he should have just learned the hex himself instead of relying on Tharja to bend to their will.

After a short while, the two unconscious bodies began to stir. Resisting the urge to help Robin's body, which he was sure no longer contained Robin, he rushed over to his old body, gently lifting its head off the ground. "Robin, are you alright?" he asked. Obviously she wouldn't be completely alright, but he wanted to make sure she wasn't hurt after Tharja had collapsed in his body.

"I... Huh?" Robin was incredibly surprised by the sound of her new voice. She sat up almost immediately, and started down at the body she now possessed, her face flushing a bright red. "I... I have your body," she mumbled.

"Mmm, now this is much better," Robin's voice sounded from near the entrance of the tent. Tharja was awake, and appeared to be hugging herself.

"Tharja... why?" Robin asked, not completely understanding Tharja's actions.

"No matter what I did, you refused to accept my advances. I couldn't even win you over by becoming the object of your affection. So if I can't have you, then I'll take the next best thing." She had a gleeful smile on her face the entire time she was speaking, the kind of smile neither Chrom nor Robin had seen on Tharja's actual face before.

"Tharja-" Chrom started, only to be cut off immediately.

"Don't bother trying to talk me out of this. This is my body now, and I'm not giving it up for anything." This all seemed a bit unhinged, even by Tharja's standards. However, considering she was the one with mastery over dark magic here, there wasn't much Chrom could do if she refused.

"At least swap Chrom and myself, then," Robin suggested. "Chrom doesn't deserve to be stuck in your body just because you want to keep mine." While she would have preferred to have her own body back and have everything be normal again, Robin was prepared to accept being stuck in Tharja's body if it meant Chrom was able to have his own body back.

"Doesn't he? He's the one who stole you away from me in the first place, I think he's getting exactly what he deserves." She stood up from the ground and dusted off her coat. "Now if you'll excuse me, I'm afraid my tactics have gotten a little rusty, so I don't have a plan for the upcoming battle," she said, clearly trying to play the part of Robin. "I'm sure you two can come up with something without me, though. I'll be in my tent if you need me." With that, she simply walked out of the tent, Chrom and Robin helpless to stop her.

Chrom let out a disappointed sigh, his head dropping down. "I'm sorry about getting you involved in this," Chrom said, still hating that it was Tharja's voice coming out of his mouth. "This would never have happened if I'd just tried to sort this out on my own."

"Don't be," Robin replied, coming down from the shock of being in Chrom's body to find herself somewhat uncomfortable. "Neither of us could have predicted how far Tharja would take this."

The two sat in silence for a moment, before Chrom asked, "So, what do we do now?"

"Well," Robin started as she stood up, adjusting to her new centre of gravity, "you asked me here to talk strategy for the upcoming battle, right?"

"Yeah." Chrom stood up as well, not wobbling as much as he had the first time. While he wouldn't call himself "comfortable" in Tharja's body, he had certainly gotten a bit more used to it now that he'd had to walk around in it for a while.

"In that case, that's probably what we should do. This isn't ideal, but for the time being, I suppose it'll be my job to lead the Shepherds, and we can't lead them into battle without a plan. I will still need your help, though. I may be a good tactician, but I'm not much of a leader."

"Of course," Chrom said, nodding. He wasn't exactly pleased that he and Robin had been forced into bodies other than their own, but he was at least glad that someone he trusted was in charged, and was willing to do whatever he could to help out.
1112322222112212221112.title: Tharja has other plans

111232222211221222112.content:
After a long pause, Tharja gave a rather short reply. "No."

"What?" Robin and Chrom both exclaimed. Had their plan failed?

"I am a prince now, and commander of this army. Why would I go back to being an outsider that everyone looks down upon and thinks is creepy or something of the like? You refused to accept me in my own body, despite my attempts, should I immediately give up this one when it might still bear fruit?"

"Yes! Yes you should give it up! It's not your body!" Robin practically shouted at Tharja. "You can't just steal someone's life like that!" Chrom simply stood shocked in silence. Tharja was completely dead set on keeping his body, and for more reasons than just Robin, it seemed.

"I can. And I have," Tharja stated rather confidently. "Now, are we going to have our strategy meeting, or am I going to need to start searching for a new tactician?"

After a moment of silence, and a heavy sigh, Robin approached Chrom again, talking to him quietly. "Head back to Tharja's tent for now."

"What?" Chrom exclaimed, a little louder than he probably should have. Were they just giving up?"

"Just listen. Go to Tharja's tent and see if you can find anything on the hex she used. Bring anything you can find back to my tent. I'll meet you there after the strategy meeting."

"O-Okay."

With a nod and a reassuring smile, Chrom turned back towards Tharja. "Alright, "Chrom", let's have this meeting then," she said.

Though they could have started immediately, Tharja seemed to wait until Chrom had left. Regardless, what was going on in there was none of Chrom's concern now. Robin could fill him in on the strategy later if he was back to being himself by then. Moving with purpose, he swiftly marched his way over to Tharja's tent, doing everything in his power to ignore the feminine way her body moved.

The inside was a bit of a mess, leaving Chrom at a loss for where to begin. A large collection of tomes lay scattered around the tent, and there was quite the assortment of ingredients that he assumed Tharja used for her hexes. He knew there had to be some sort of information about the hex here, he just needed to find it.

The was also the matter of casting the hex itself. Thankfully, the battle soon ended with the Shepherds emerging victorious, with the Mad King Gangrel dead at Chrom’s hands. With the battle over, Lucina continued to watch her father from a distance. She knew that Chrom had proposed to her mother just after the battle with Gangrel’s forces had ended, and she wanted to see how it happened for herself.

However, when she reached her father, he wasn’t with her mother, he was still with Panne, who had saved his life earlier.

“Is there something you wanted?” Panne asked.

“I wanted to thank you again for saving my life,” said Chrom. “And for fighting Gangrel alongside me. I know it’s not what my sister would’ve wanted...”

“Stop,” said Panne. “You did what was necessary to defend your people. Your sister’s goals were admirable, but there was no reasoning with Gangrel.”

“I know,” said Chrom.

“Then, if there is nothing else, I will take my leave,” said Panne as she turned to walk away.

“Wait!” said Chrom. “There... is one other thing.”

“Oh?” said Panne.

“When we were fighting together,” said Chrom. “It was unlike anything I’ve ever felt before. When you’re close, I feel safer.”

“I... I must admit, seeing you safe... it makes me happy,” said Panne. “I haven’t felt like this since...”

“Since the death of your family,” said Chrom.

“Yes,” said Panne. “While I still miss them, being with you... it gives me hope, that someday, I will be able to remember them without pain.”

“I know,” said Chrom. “Emmeryn’s death... I know it doesn’t compare to what you went through...”

“It does not,” said Panne. “But that does not diminish the pain you are feeling. And, despite my opinions regarding humanity... I am sorry for your loss.”

“Thank you,” said Chrom. “That means a great deal to me... maybe, together, we can heal each other.”

“What do you mean?” Panne asked.

“Here,” said Chrom, reaching into a pocket and pulling something out. “I want you to have this.”

“This is... a ring,” said Panne as she accepted the ring. “And it bears the crest of Ylisse.”

“Yes,” said Chrom. “My parents had it made to celebrate my birth. They wanted me to give it to the woman I would want to spend the rest of my life with.”

“Are you asking me to be your mate?” Panne asked, blushing.

“I... I guess I am,” said Chrom as he knelt down and took one of Panne’s hands. “Panne, will you marry me?”

“...Yes,” said Panne, with a soft smile. “Yes, I believe I will.”

Lucina, watching from her hiding place, gasped in surprise. This wasn’t how things were supposed to go! Panne wasn’t supposed to marry Chrom! But if Panne was now going to marry Chrom, then that meant...

Lucina clutched at her head as she felt a horrible pain welling up inside her, as if her entire body was being violently reshaped. The pain grew to be too much for her, and she passed out. She woke up a few minutes later, and when she came to her senses, she had a feeling that Panne becoming Chrom’s wife had caused her to change as well. Lucina drew her Falchion, and held it up so that the blade caught her reflection.

It didn't take long for Tharja to find a hex that amused her, and should suit her purpose fairly well. The hex should combine Sumia with her mount, creating a strange combination of man and beast that Robin should hopefully never fall for. A devilish grin spread across Tharja's face as she cast the hex, watching from the shadows as the scenario unfolded.

Sumia, unaware that anything was wrong, simply continued to groom her pegasus. "Good girl," she said to her pegasus, making sure to keep her calm, "It won't be long now. This war will be over any day now."

Suddenly, Sumia found herself lifted up into the air, prompting her to let out a yelp and drop the brush she was using, before being put down on on her pegasus' back. "What's going on!?" she shouted, looking around the stable for someone who might be doing this. However, she was unable to spot anyone as Tharja had hidden herself well enough to avoid detection. She tried to get off her pegasus, but found herself unable to move her legs, or even lift herself of its back.

"Why... why can't I..." She heard her pegasus let out a panicked neigh, redirecting her attention to the beast she was riding. To her surprise, her pegasus' head and neck seemed to be shrinking. "What!? What's happening to you?" It wasn't just the pegasus, though. Sumia noticed she seemed to be shifting forward along the pegasus' back to fill the space. She tried in vain to push herself off the pegasus' back, or at least back away from its shrinking head, but to no avail. Worse still, her legs seemed to be sinking inside the pegasus' body. She was loosing feeling in her lower half, but gaining an entirely new set of feelings to replace them. She cover her eyes with her hands, not daring to look again until it was over.

Eventually, her pegasus stopped neighing, and the shifting feelings stopped. Sumia slowly lowered her hands. Her pegasus' head had completely vanished, and sitting in its place was her body, from the waist up. She no longer had her own human legs, but she had a slew of new feelings coming from her lower half. She could feel the thin layer of hair coating her equine lower half, the hooves she had for feet, the tail coming out of her rear. She had four legs instead of two, and a pair of wings as well. She slowly tried to lift her leg, watching as her front left leg lifted up off the ground. It felt different from moving her old legs. She put it back down, not trusting herself to move around on four legs yet, especially with how clumsy she usually was.

The entire time, Tharja had been watching from the shadows. This hadn't exactly been what she had in mind when she thought about combining Sumia with her pegasus, but it should work just as well. Sumia was no longer completely human, and that should hopefully be enough to stop Robin from falling for her.

1113322212112211.content:
Tharja watched as Cordelia opened the door to the stables and gently guided Sumia out, using one of her wings to steady Sumia's horse body. Once the two pegasus centaurs were out of sight, Tharja stepped out of the stables and had a quick look around. She saw Robin speaking with Chrom, presumably about strategies for tomorrow's skirmish against the Risen horde that had appeared near the Breakneck Pass. Neither of the two men noticed her as she walked away from the stables towards where the tents for the Shepherds had been set up. A few guards were on patrol as she made her way over to her tent. They were used to seeing her coming and going at odd hours, usually leaving to search for ingredients for her hexes, or returning from said searches.

Tharja pulled back the flap of her tent and looked around quickly, and was thankful that no-one had entered the tent while she was away, though she did notice that the ingredients for the hex she used on Sumia had turned to ash, as she'd expected. Tharja entered her tent and closed the flap behind her, and let out a sigh of relief. Thankfully, none of the Shepherds had seen her entering or exiting the stables, meaning that none of them knew what she had done to Sumia... and to Cordelia as well, apparently. Tharja moved the jars containing the various preserved animal parts she used in her hexes to reveal a book, an old leather-bound grimoire written in an ancient tongue that had contained the hex she had cast. Tharja flipped through the yellowed pages until she reached the page she was looking for, then pulled out a notebook that contained her efforts at translating the grimoire's text. She quickly scanned her translation, then retrieved a Plegian textbook that contained translations of the ancient tongue, and started re-translating the grimoire's text on a new page in her notebook.

Having become somewhat fluent in the ancient tongue thanks to her hours of study with her initial translations, her second translation only took her about an hour, compared to the three hours it had taken her to translate the page the first time. When she was done, she compared her first translation with her newest translation. The first part of the text detailed the effects of the hex, which was designed to combine a human and a beast into a single creature. The second part of the text listed the ingredients needed to cast the hex, and that was where Tharja noticed a discrepancy between her initial translation and her second translation. Tharja checked the original lines in the grimoire and compared them to the translation textbook and grimaced.

While she had correctly translated each of the ingredients, she had made an error in translating the amount of each ingredient required in her initial translation. In her first translation, she had mistranslated the number one for a number ten, and such had collected ten of each ingredient, rather than a single specimen of each ingredient. Suddenly, the warning listed under the instructions for casting the hex made a lot more sense. Tharja felt her stomach tie itself in knots as she read the translations of the final part of the page. It was a warning that explained that increasing the ingredients would cause the power of the hex exponentially. Tharja flipped over a page in her notebook and started jotting down numbers as she figured out just how powerful the hex had been.

"Let's see," she muttered to herself. "If one set of ingredients is the baseline, then two sets would double it, three sets would be four times more powerful than one set..." Tharja trailed off as she continued through to ten sets of ingredients. Her eyes went wide as she calculated how powerful tens sets of ingredients would be, then went back through the set of numbers again to check her math. Tharja felt her throat go dry as she wrote down the final calculations. By using ten of each ingredient instead of one, she had caused the hex to be over five hundred times more powerful, and Tharja dreaded that she had altered the very fabric of reality itself by casting such a powerful hex. She picked up the grimoire and looked at the page opposite the hex she used. Tharja returned to her notebook and quickly translated the first few lines of the next page of the grimoire, and sighed in relief as she realised the next hex in the grimoire was one that would reverse the effects of the one she had just cast. However, Tharja was worried that she might not be able to translate the text and gather the ingredients in time. She was loathe to admit it, but if she wanted to try and reverse the hex she had cast, she would probably need help. Tharja briefly considered going to Robin, but quickly dismissed the idea. Robin would no doubt be upset that she had cast the hex in the first place, and probably wasn't fluent in the ancient tongue, so she couldn't rely on his help for translating the grimoire. That meant that the next best candidate would probably be Miriel. The scholarly mage would probably have some familiarity with the ancient tongue, which would allow them to work together to translate the grimoire, and Tharja figured she could probably convince Miriel to keep quiet and help by convincing her it was for the purposes of discovery.

Tharja yawned, and glanced outside her tent. The sun was starting to set, and Tharja suddenly became acutely aware of just how tired she was. Casting such a powerful hex had been surprisingly draining, and her concentration and focus on her translations probably hadn't helped. Tharja yawned again and considered her options. She could go and see Miriel now and try and enlist her help, or she could turn in for the night and go to sleep. Of course, the longer she waited, it would become more difficult to reverse the hex she had cast. What should she do?

It would be a better idea to get some rest now, and focus her efforts on reversing this hex in the morning.

She had not only combined Sumia with her pegasus, like she'd intended to do, but she had also done the same to Cordelia, and oddly enough, Cordelia didn't seem to notice anything amiss, and considering she didn't hear any screams or shouts when Cordelia and Sumia left the stable, she assumed the rest of the camp found it normal. With the reality altering effects in play, Tharja couldn't help but wonder why Sumia had still freaked out when the spell was cast. Perhaps being at the epicenter of the hex caused her to be immune to the reality warping effects, making her just as clueless as Tharja was about the new reality that had been created.

Even still, something didn't seem right. What she'd done was certainly more powerful than the hex's intended result, but it didn't seem over 500 times more powerful. Was there something she was missing, or had she simply not had a chance to see everything it had done yet. She knew it hadn't effected everyone, as she was still normal, as were Chrom, Robin, and the guards she saw on the way over here. Perhaps her spell only effected Pegasus Knights? Had she created a world where pegasi no longer existed, while the Pegasus Knight class was filled by half-human, half-pegasus people? That would explain why she hadn't seen any other changes, as Chrom's army only contained two Pegasus Knights that she knew of; Sumia and Cordelia.

Regardless, there was nothing she could do at the moment. In the morning, she would focus her efforts on reversing this hex, and perhaps trying one that wouldn't result in the fabric of reality being warped. Little by little, her fatigue from the day's events overcame her, and she drifted off to sleep.

As Tharja awoke, the first thought to hit her mind was that something felt wrong. Her barely awake mind couldn't tell what it was, but there was something not right. Her eyes slowly opened, staring at the pillow her face had been pressed onto. She didn't remember going to sleep on her stomach, and she wasn't normally the type to roll around in her sleep, so this struck her as odd. She rolled over onto her back, and that's when she realised what exactly it was that her mind felt was wrong.

Her legs were gone, and in their place, a long snake-like tail, extending past the length of her original legs, off the edge of the bed, and then for a few metres further on the ground. She reached out and touched it, to confirm what she was seeing, feeling not only the scales beneath hear fingers, but also her hand running along where her hips should be. This was definitely real; her legs had been replaced with the body of a snake.

For a moment, several emotions ran rampant through Tharja's mind; confusion, panic, anger, fear. However, it soon dawned on her that this was not a curse placed upon her by someone else, nor something she could easily reverse. "The hex wasn't done," she mumbled, noticing her tongue felt different, but lacking the mirror to investigate. She realised that the observed effects of her hex were not enough to quantify the hex being over five hundred times more powerful than it should be, but she hadn't expected that it not yet complete, nor that she herself would fall victim to it. Now the extent of her hex worried her even further. Clearly it was not limited to pegasus knights, nor simply to riders and their mounts. Would it simply turn anyone into a human-animal hybrid? How far would it reach? To those here in the Shepherds' camp? To all of Ylisse? To the whole world? Then there was the question of where her snake body came from. When Sumia had become a pegasus-centaur, she'd simply fused together with her pegasus, but with Frederick guarding the camp, Tharja doubted a snake would ever get close enough to her tent for her to fuse with. Not to mention, she'd never encountered a snake as large as her current body outside of myths and fairy tales. Had the hex simply transformed her outright, turning her into a combination of man and beast rather than literally combining her with an existing beast?

At the very least, if yesterday's encounter was anything to go by, Tharja should have to worry about causing a panic, as the spell was so powerful that it altered reality to ensure that these new human-animal hybrids would be treated as if they were normal. Tharja was thankful that despite the hex morphing her own body, she was not also victim to its reality warping effects, likely due to being the one who cast the hex in the first place. Unless circumstances had changed overnight, Sumia was likely also aware due to being at the epicenter of the hex, and was probably still somewhat panicked about why she and others were suddenly becoming hybrids.

Regardless of the warping reality, Tharja had no intention on being half snake for the rest of her life, so she needed to reverse this hex as soon as possible. She quickly sat up, swinging her tail around to the side of the bed, when suddenly she felt somewhat dizzy. A loud gurgling sound from her stomach alerted her to the cause. She felt incredibly famished, and despite having just woken up, she still felt tired, if not more so than when she'd gone to bed. She supposed this was only natural, as the hex had continued to work its magic throughout the night, draining on her energy. Getting any work done in this state would be a tough order, but if she put it off to try and replenish her enter, the hex could just continue to push onwards, assuming it wasn't complete yet. Either way, she knew she should probably seek help with translating the reversal hex, to prevent making a mistake as she had yesterday. Provided she could actually convince someone that reality had changed, that is.

Tharja winced as another pang of hunger shot through her body. She had no idea why she was so hungry, but she wasn’t going to wait around for the rest of the camp to wake up and prepare breakfast. She needed to eat, and that meant she needed to go hunting. She removed her dark mage cape and tossed it aside, not wanting it to get in the way during her hunt. With that done, she slithered out of her tent, and slipped out of the Shepherd’s camp and into the wilderness surrounding the clearing. The Shepherds had set up camp just to the north of a small forest east of Breakneck Pass, and Tharja entered the forest, keeping her human body low to the ground as she weaved her snake body between the trees. Tharja’s forked tongue poked out of a small divot in her lips, tasting the air before slipping back into her mouth. Tharja could taste the scents of smaller animals, like foxes and rabbits, as well as the scents of larger animals like deer, and possibly even a bear. She headed deeper into the forest, her tongue constantly darting out of her mouth and back in, slowly getting a better idea of what was in the forest, and how close her potential prey might be.

After about fifteen minutes, Tharja stopped. She was well inside the forest now, and she sat still for a minute, her tongue poking out and back in as she tasted the air, getting a sense for what was around her. The taste of fox fur and rabbit blood was in the air, suggesting that a fox had recently caught a rabbit for breakfast. However, rabbit didn’t interest her; they were far too small, and she doubted that she could find enough to sate her hunger. She could also taste bear, though it was faint, at least a few days old. Her tongue continued sampling the air, and she could taste deer somewhere to the southwest, somewhere close. Tharja lowered her body and slithered to the southwest, keeping her arms close to her sides as she slithered around the trees. Her tongue was darting in and out of her mouth faster now, giving her a better sense of the deer’s trail. Her eyes scanned the trees ahead of her, looking for any signs of the deer.

Tharja stopped as movement to her right caught her eye. She turned her head slowly, and saw a deer walking through the forest, stopping to sniff the air. Tharja lowered herself to the ground and began inching towards the deer ever so slowly. The deer had its back to her as she got closer and closer, her large snake body making no sound as it slithered forward. Tharja opened her mouth and smiled, exposing her two long fangs, dripping with venom. As she got within striking distance, a soft chuckle escaped her throat. The deer turned to face the sound and spotted her, but it was too late. Tharja lunged forward, opening her mouth wide as she struck. Her aim was true, and her teeth sank into the deer’s neck. Tharja savoured the warm tang of the deer’s blood as venom shot out of her fangs into the deer. The deer struggled, trying to tear itself from her mouth’s grip, but Tharja wrapped her arms around the deer’s body, holding it still as she emptied her venom sacs. Once she was sure the deer had enough venom in its blood, she opened her mouth again, pulling her fangs out of the deer’s neck.

Tharja let the deer go, and licked the blood from her lips as the deer staggered off into the forest. Tharja followed the wounded deer at a leisurely pace for a few minutes, tracking it by the scent of the blood dripping from its neck. After a few minutes, the venom in the deer’s bloodstream finished its work, and the deer collapsed, dead. With her prey dead, Tharja slithered up to it. She grabbed the deer’s legs and tucked them up close to the body, then slithered around to the deer’s rear. Tharja picked the deer up by its rear and lifted it up to her mouth. She unhinged her lower jaw, allowing her mouth to open much wider and lower than normal, and began stuffing the deer into her mouth. It took Tharja the better part of five minutes to get the deer down her throat, but she finally managed to get the head into her mouth. Once the deer’s head was past her lips, she closed her mouth and swallowed, her neck and human upper body bulging as muscles began pushing the deer down past her human body and into the digestive system located in her snake body. After about two minutes of swallowing, Tharja had managed to get the deer into her snake body’s stomach, bringing her human upper body back to normal proportions.

Tharja sighed in contentment, basking herself in the light of the rising sun, satisfied by her successful hunt. However, as pleasant as sunning herself was, she needed to get back to the Shepherd’s camp.
